Award.AwardTitle: Using Stress and Warning to Improve Eyewitness Memory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Faulty eyewitness reports have contributed to approximately 70% of wrongful convictions in the United States (Innocence Project, 2016). What gives rise to such faulty reports? Research has revealed that eyewitness memory can be contaminated by false or inaccurate information (misinformation). Exposure to misinformation can occur through the course of interviews and questioning, discussions with co-witnesses, or from information garnered from the media and other external sources. Given that these are the circumstances routinely faced by eyewitnesses, it is imperative that researchers understand how to mitigate susceptibility to misinformation so that such memory errors can be avoided. This project aims to identify a resource-minimal, evidence-based practice that can be employed to protect the integrity of eyewitness memory reports. The research will focus on the effects of warning eyewitnesses about the threat of misinformation. Warnings have previously been incorporated into other areas of legal practice with great success. For example, the Department of Justice (1999) recommended that law officials warn eyewitnesses that a guilty suspect may not be present prior to conducting a lineup -- a practice that significantly reduces false identifications. By 2013, approximately 90% of surveyed police departments adopted this practice. The current project uses a cognitive and neural approach to test whether a similar practice can reduce faulty eyewitness reports. The research team will disseminate the results through seminars with local legal communities to assure the impact of this research on the public.

Research reveals that memory errors can be reduced when eyewitnesses are warned that external sources can contaminate memory for an event. For example, when warned about the veracity of information given to an eyewitness after an event, participants were less likely to incorporate such information into memory reports. However, providing a warning after exposure to false or inaccurate information (misinformation) does not entirely eliminate misinformation errors. Is there an optimal time to warn eyewitnesses? Experiment One will reveal the most effective time to warn eyewitness about the threat of misinformation. Such evidence will be especially useful to the legal community. Despite a bulk of research on warning in the context of misinformation, no study has used neuroscientific methods --thus, how warning modulates neural activity to protect memory remains unknown. Accordingly, Experiment Two will employ functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to examine the manner in which warning modulates neural activity to ultimately reduce eyewitness memory errors. This experiment will directly enhance our understanding of the complex mechanisms that support human memory processes in the context of the eyewitness. Lastly, it is noteworthy that misinformation errors that are induced by repeated interviewing have been observed even under optimal conditions for learning and memory. Thus, the inherent stress experienced by eyewitnesses -- from the onset of the witnessed event, during the retrieval of such events, and extending to courtroom testimony -- may pose an even greater risk for memory errors. For this reason, Experiment Three will assess whether warning can reduce eyewitness susceptibility to misinformation under conditions of stress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
According to the Innocence Project, false eyewitness reports have contributed to approximately 70% of wrongful convictions. Despite efforts by the Department of Justice to create evidence-based standards in interview practices across police departments, the majority of surveyed police departments have failed to implement such recommendations due to difficulties in providing training and/or a lack of resources. Given the critical role that eyewitnesses play in criminal investigations and prosecutions, an interdisciplinary research team sought to investigate the simple and resource-minimal practice of warning eyewitnesses about the threat of misinformation to improve the accuracy of their memory reports. Accordingly, experiments employing behavioral, neuroscientific, and physiological methods were conducted to understand when warnings are most effective and the underlying mechanisms by which warnings act to protect memory from distortion.

Repeatedly interviewing eyewitnesses can increase the likelihood that memory reports will become contaminated by misinformation?externally presented post-event information. During criminal investigations, eyewitnesses may become exposed to misinformation through the course of interviews and questioning, through discussions with co-witnesses, and from information garnered from the media and other external sources. The present set of experiments revealed that providing eyewitnesses with a simple warning about the threat of misinformation significantly improved memory accuracy and reduced susceptibility to misinformation. Furthermore, the researchers found that this memory benefit occurs regardless of whether warnings are provided proactively (before exposure to misinformation) or retroactively (after exposure to misinformation). In addition, functional neuroimaging revealed the neural mechanism by which warnings improve memory accuracy. In the brain, the protective effect of warning was associated with increased reactivation of sensory regions associated with witnessing the original event and decreased reactivation of sensory regions associated with hearing the misleading information. These findings suggest that warnings can protect memory from misinformation by modulating reconstructive processes at the time of memory retrieval. In addition to having important theoretical implications for cognitive and neural models of memory retrieval, these findings have important practical implications for improving the accuracy of eyewitness testimony as well as everyday memory reports. Highlighting the potential for impact of the proposed practice of warning, warnings have been particularly well-received in other areas of the legal system. For example, in 1999, the Department of Justice recommended that law officials warn eyewitnesses that a guilty suspect may not be present prior to conducting a lineup, which significantly reduces false identifications. By 2013, approximately 90% of surveyed police departments adopted this particular practice. 

In summary, the present experiments directly enhance our understanding of the complex mechanisms that support human memory processes in the context of the eyewitness and the factors that can protect or endanger the integrity of eyewitness memory reports. More specifically, the researchers made important discoveries about the most effective time to warn eyewitnesses about the threat of misinformation and elucidated the manner in which warnings modulate neural activity during memory retrieval. Some of these results have been published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of the Sciences (Karanian, Rabb, Wulff, Torrance, Thomas, & Race, 2020) and a second manuscript is under review at the Journal of Experimental Psychology: Learning, Memory, and Cognition (Wulf, Karanian, Race, & Thomas, under review). The research team also presented this work at a variety of scientific conferences, including the Society for Applied Research in Memory and Cognition, American Psychology and Law Society, Psychonomics Society, and the Cognitive Neuroscience Society. Most recently, the research team continues to investigate the value of warnings in the context of the eyewitness. Of particular interest, the inherent stress experienced by eyewitnesses ? from the onset of the witnessed event, during the retrieval of such events, and extending to courtroom testimony ? may pose an even greater risk for memory errors. For this reason, the researchers are investigating whether warning can also reduce eyewitness susceptibility to misinformation under conditions of stress.
